solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input resetn,
input [3:1] r,
output [3:1] g
);
reg [1:0] state;
reg [1:0] next_state;
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (!resetn) begin
state <= 2'b00; // A
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @* begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // A
if (r[1]) begin
next_state = 2'b01; // B
end else if (r[2]) begin
next_state = 2'b10; // C
end else if (r[3]) begin
next_state = 2'b11; // D
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // A
end
end
2'b01: begin // B
if (r[1]) begin
next_state = 2'b01; // B
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // A
end
end
2'b10: begin // C
if (r[2]) begin
next_state = 2'b10; // C
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // A
end
end
2'b11: begin // D
if (r[3]) begin
next_state = 2'b11; // D
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // A
end
end
endcase
end
assign g[1] = (state == 2'b01); // B
assign g[2] = (state == 2'b10); // C
assign g[3] = (state == 2'b11); // D
endmodule
endmodule

module top_module (
input clk,
input resetn,
input x,
input y,
output f,
output g
);
reg [3:0] state, next_state;
always @(posedge clk or negedge resetn) begin
if (!resetn) begin
state <= 4'b0000; // A state
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @* begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin // A state
if (x) begin
next_state = 4'b0010; // B state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // A state
end
end
4'b0010: begin // B state
next_state = 4'b1000; // S0 state
end
4'b1000: begin // S0 state
if (x) begin
next_state = 4'b1001; // S1 state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1000; // S0 state
end
end
4'b1001: begin // S1 state
if (x) begin
next_state = 4'b1001; // S1 state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1010; // S10 state
end
end
4'b1010: begin // S10 state
if (x) begin
next_state = 4'b1100; // G1 state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1000; // S0 state
end
end
4'b1100: begin // G1 state
if (y) begin
next_state = 4'b1110; // P1 state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1111; // G2 state
end
end
4'b1111: begin // G2 state
if (y) begin
next_state = 4'b1110; // P1 state
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1101; // P0 state
end
end
4'b1101: begin // P0 state
next_state = 4'b1101; // P0 state
end
4'b1110: begin // P1 state
next_state = 4'b1110; // P1 state
end
endcase
end
assign f = (state == 4'b0010); // B state
assign g = (state == 4'b1100) || (state == 4'b1111) || (state == 4'b1110); // G1 or G2 or P1 state
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module (
	input clk,
	input resetn,
	input x,
	input y,
	output f,
	output g
);
detail_description: Consider a finite state machine that is used to control some type of motor. The FSM has inputs x and y, which come from the motor, and produces outputs f and g, which control the motor. There is also a clock input called clk and a reset input (synchronous, active low) called resetn. The FSM has to work as follows. As long as the reset input is asserted, the FSM stays in a beginning state, called state A. When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. When x has produced the values 1, 0, 1 in three successive clock cycles, then g should be set to 1 on the following clock cycle. While maintaining g = 1 the FSM has to monitor the y input. If y has the value 1 within at most two clock cycles, then the FSM should maintain g = 1 permanently (that is, until reset). But if y does not become 1 within two clock cycles, then the FSM should set g = 0 permanently (until reset).

solution:
`timescale 1ns / 1ps
module top_module (
input clk,
input resetn,
input x,
input y,
output f,
output g
);
reg [1:0] state, next_state;
reg f_reg, g_reg;
always @(posedge clk or negedge resetn) begin
if (!resetn) begin
state <= 2'b00; // State A
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @(state, x, y) begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // State A
f_reg <= 1'b0;
g_reg <= 1'b0;
if (resetn && x) begin
next_state <= 2'b01; // State B
end else begin
next_state <= state;
end
end
2'b01: begin // State B
f_reg <= 1'b1;
g_reg <= 1'b0;
if (x) begin
next_state <= 2'b10; // State C
end else begin
next_state <= state;
end
end
2'b10: begin // State C
f_reg <= 1'b0;
g_reg <= 1'b0;
if (x) begin
next_state <= 2'b11; // State D
end else begin
next_state <= state;
end
end
2'b11: begin // State D
f_reg <= 1'b0;
if (x) begin
next_state <= 2'b11; // State D
end else if (y) begin
g_reg <= 1'b1;
next_state <= 2'b11; // State D
end else begin
g_reg <= 1'b0;
next_state <= 2'b00; // State A
end
end
endcase
end
assign f = f_reg;
assign g = g_reg;
endmodule

When the reset signal is de-asserted, then after the next clock edge the FSM has to set the output f to 1 for one clock cycle. Then, the FSM has to monitor the x input. solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input resetn,
input x,
input y,
output f,
output g
);
reg [3:0] state;
reg f_reg;
reg g_reg;
always @(posedge clk or negedge resetn) begin
if (!resetn) begin
state <= 4'b0000; // A state
end else begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin // A state
if (x) begin
state <= 4'b0010; // B state
end
end
4'b0010: begin // B state
state <= 4'b0001; // S0 state
end
4'b0001: begin // S0 state
if (x) begin
state <= 4'b0011; // S1 state
end
end
4'b0011: begin // S1 state
if (!x) begin
state <= 4'b1010; // S10 state
end
end
4'b1010: begin // S10 state
if (x) begin
state <= 4'b1100; // G1 state
end else begin
state <= 4'b0001; // S0 state
end
end
4'b1100: begin // G1 state
if (y) begin
state <= 4'b1110; // P1 state
end else begin
state <= 4'b1000; // G2 state
end
end
4'b1000: begin // G2 state
if (y) begin
state <= 4'b1110; // P1 state
end else begin
state <= 4'b1101; // P0 state
end
end
4'b1101: begin // P0 state
state <= 4'b1101; // P0 state
end
4'b1110: begin // P1 state
state <= 4'b1110; // P1 state
end
endcase
end
end
always @(state) begin
f_reg = (state == 4'b0010); // B state
g_reg = (state == 4'b1100) || (state == 4'b1000) || (state == 4'b1110); // G1 or G2 or P1 state
end
assign f = f_reg;
assign g = g_reg;
endmodule
endmodule

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input reset,
input x,
output reg z
);
reg [2:0] state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 3'b001; // Initialize state to A
end else begin
case (state)
3'b000: begin // State A
if (x) begin
state <= 3'b010; // Next state is B
end else begin
state <= 3'b000; // Next state is A
end
end
3'b001: begin // State B
if (x) begin
state <= 3'b101; // Next state is E
end else begin
state <= 3'b001; // Next state is B
end
end
3'b010: begin // State C
if (x) begin
state <= 3'b001; // Next state is B
end else begin
state <= 3'b010; // Next state is C
end
end
3'b011: begin // State D
if (x) begin
state <= 3'b010; // Next state is C
end else begin
state <= 3'b010; // Next state is B
end
end
3'b100: begin // State E
if (x) begin
state <= 3'b100; // Next state is E
end else begin
state <= 3'b011; // Next state is D
end
end
default: begin
state <= 3'b001; // Default state is A
end
endcase
end
end
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (state == 3'b100 || state == 3'b101) begin // State D or E
z <= 1'b1; // Output is high
end else begin
z <= 1'b0; // Output is low
end
end
endmodule

solution:
module top_module (
    input clk,
    input reset,
    input s,
    input w,
    output reg z
);

reg [2:0] state, next_state;

always @(posedge clk) begin
    if (reset) begin
        state <= 0;
    end else begin
        state <= next_state;
    end
end

always @(state or s or w) begin
    case (state)
        0: begin
            if (s) begin
                next_state = 1;
            end else begin
                next_state = 2;
            end
        end
        1: begin
            if (w) begin
                next_state = 4;
            end else begin
                next_state = 3;
            end
        end
        2: begin
            if (w) begin
                next_state = 5;
            end else begin
                next_state = 1;
            end
        end
        3: begin
            next_state = 1;
        end
        4: begin
            if (w) begin
                next_state = 2;
            end else begin
                next_state = 3;
            end
        end
        5: begin
            if (w) begin
                next_state = 1;
            end else begin
                next_state = 2;
            end
        end
    endcase
end

always @(posedge clk) begin
    if (reset) begin
        z <= 0;
    end else begin
        case (state)
            0: begin
                z <= 0;
            end
            1: begin
                z <= 1;
            end
            2: begin
                z <= 0;
            end
            3: begin
                z <= 1;
            end
            4: begin
                z <= 0;
            end
            5: begin
                z <= 1;
            end
        endcase
    end
end

endmodule

prompt:
module top_module (
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input s,
	input w,
	output reg z
);
detail_description: Consider a finite state machine with inputs s and w. Assume that the FSM begins in a reset state called A, as depicted below. The FSM remains in state A as long as s = 0, and it moves to state B when s = 1. Once in state B the FSM examines the value of the input w in the next three clock cycles. If w = 1 in exactly two of these clock cycles, then the FSM has to set an output z to 1 in the following clock cycle. Otherwise z has to be 0. The FSM continues checking w for the next three clock cycles, and so on. Use as few states as possible. Note that the s input is used only in state A, so you need to consider just the w input. Assume reset is active high synchronous.

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input reset,
input s,
input w,
output reg z
);
reg [3:0] state, next_state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 4'b0000; // state A
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @(state, s, w) begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin // state A
if (s) begin
next_state = 4'b0010; // state B
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // state A
end
end
4'b0010: begin // state B
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b1011; // state S11
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1010; // state S10
end
end
4'b0011: begin // state C
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b1011; // state S11
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1010; // state S10
end
end
4'b1010: begin // state S10
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b1101; // state S21
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1100; // state S20
end
end
4'b1011: begin // state S11
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b1110; // state S22
end else begin
next_state = 4'b1101; // state S21
end
end
4'b1100: begin // state S20
next_state = 4'b0010; // state B
end
4'b1101: begin // state S21
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b0011; // state C
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0010; // state B
end
end
4'b1110: begin // state S22
if (w) begin
next_state = 4'b0010; // state B
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0011; // state C
end
end
default: begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // state A
end
endcase
end
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (reset) begin
z <= 0;
end else begin
case (state)
4'b0010, 4'b0011, 4'b1010, 4'b1011, 4'b1100, 4'b1101, 4'b1110: begin
z <= 1;
end
default: begin
z <= 0;
end
endcase
end
end
endmodule

input clk,
input w,
input R,
input E,
input L,
output reg Q
);

end
end

);
detail_description: Consider an n-bit shift register circuit. Inputs E are for enabling shift, R for value to load, L is asserted when it should load, and w is the input to the first stage of the shift register. Write a Verilog module named top_module for one stage of this circuit, including both the flip-flop and multiplexers.

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input w,
input R,
input E,
input L,
output reg Q
);
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (E == 1'b0) begin
Q <= Q; // Q is held in its current state
end else begin
if (L == 1'b1) begin
Q <= R; // Q is updated with the value of R
end else begin
Q <= w; // Q is updated with the value of w
end
end
end
endmodule

solution:
module top_module (
input cpu_overheated,
output reg shut_off_computer,
input arrived,
input gas_tank_empty,
output reg keep_driving
);
always @(posedge cpu_overheated) begin
shut_off_computer <= 1;
end
always @(posedge arrived) begin
keep_driving <= ~gas_tank_empty;
end
endmodule

input a,
output reg p,
output reg q
);
always @(negedge clock) begin

end

input clk,
input load,
input [255:0] data,

end else begin

end
end

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	output reg [3:0] q);
detail_description: Build a decade counter that counts from 0 through 9, inclusive, with a period of 10. The reset input is active high synchronous, and should reset the counter to 0.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
output reg [3:0] q);
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
q <= 0;
end else begin
if (q == 9) begin
q <= 0;
end else begin
q <= q + 1;
end
end
end
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	output reg [3:0] q);
detail_description: Make a decade counter that counts 1 through 10, inclusive. The reset input is active high synchronous, and should reset the counter to 1.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
output reg [3:0] q);
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
q <= 4'b0001;
end else begin
if (q == 4'b1010) begin
q <= 4'b0001;
end else begin
q <= q + 1;
end
end
end
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
    input clk,
    input areset,
    input train_valid,
    input train_taken,
    output logic [1:0] state
);
detail_description: Build a two-bit saturating counter. The counter increments (up to a maximum of 3) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 1. It decrements (down to a minimum of 0) when train_valid = 1 and train_taken = 0. When not training (train_valid = 0), the counter keeps its value unchanged. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the counter to weakly not-taken (2'b01). Output state[1:0] is the two-bit counter value.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input areset,
input train_valid,
input train_taken,
output logic [1:0] state
);
logic [1:0] next_state;
always_ff @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset) begin
state <= 1;
end else if (train_valid) begin
case (state)
0: begin
if (train_taken) begin
next_state <= 1;
end else begin
next_state <= 0;
end
end
1: begin
if (train_taken) begin
next_state <= 2;
end else begin
next_state <= 0;
end
end
2: begin
if (train_taken) begin
next_state <= 3;
end else begin
next_state <= 1;
end
end
3: begin
if (train_taken) begin
next_state <= 3;
end else begin
next_state <= 2;
end
end
default: next_state <= 0;
endcase
end else begin
next_state <= state;
end
end
always_ff @(posedge clk) begin
state <= next_state;
end
endmodule

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input slowena,
input reset,
output reg [3:0] q);
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
q <= 0;
end else if (slowena) begin
if (q == 9) begin
q <= 0;
end else begin
q <= q + 1;
end
end
end
endmodule

detail_description: Implement a Mealy-type finite state machine that recognizes the sequence "101" on an input signal named x. Your FSM should have an output signal, z, that is asserted to logic-1 when the "101" sequence is detected. Your FSM should also have a negative edge triggered asynchronous reset. You may only have 3 states in your state machine. Your FSM should recognize overlapping sequences.

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input aresetn,
input x,
output reg z
);
reg [3:0] state, next_state;
parameter S = 4'b0000;
parameter S1 = 4'b0001;
parameter S10 = 4'b0010;
always @(posedge clk or negedge aresetn) begin
if (~aresetn) begin
state <= S;
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @(state, x) begin
case (state)
S: begin
if (x == 1'b0) begin
next_state = S;
end else begin
next_state = S1;
end
end
S1: begin
if (x == 1'b0) begin
next_state = S10;
end else begin
next_state = S1;
end
end
S10: begin
if (x == 1'b0) begin
next_state = S;
end else begin
next_state = S1;
end
end
endcase
end
always @(state) begin
case (state)
S, S1: begin
z = 1'b0;
end
S10: begin
z = x;
end
endcase
end
endmodule
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input [31:0] in,
	output reg [31:0] out);
detail_description: For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
input [31:0] in,
output reg [31:0] out);
reg [31:0] out_reg;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
out_reg <= 0;
end else begin
out_reg <= in;
end
end
always @(posedge clk) begin
out <= out_reg & (~in);
end
endmodule

	input clk,

	input [31:0] in,

detail_description: For each bit in a 32-bit vector, capture when the input signal changes from 1 in one clock cycle to 0 the next. "Capture" means that the output will remain 1 until the register is reset (active high synchronous reset).

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input [7:0] in,
output reg [7:0] pedge);
reg [7:0] d_last;
always @(posedge clk) begin
d_last <= in;

module top_module (
input clk,
input in,
input areset,
output out
);
reg state, next_state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset) begin
state <= 1'b0;
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @(state, in) begin
case (state)
1'b0: begin
if (in) begin
next_state = 1'b0;
end else begin
next_state = 1'b1;
end
end
1'b1: begin
if (in) begin
next_state = 1'b1;
end else begin
next_state = 1'b0;
end
end
endcase
end
assign out = (state == 1'b1) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0;
endmodule

module top_module (
input clk,
input in,
input areset,
output out
);
reg [1:0] state;
reg out_reg;
always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset)
state <= 2'b10; // Reset to state B
else begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // State A
if (in)
state <= 2'b01; // Transition to state A
else
state <= 2'b10; // Transition to state B
end
2'b01: begin // State B
if (in)
state <= 2'b01; // Transition to state B
else
state <= 2'b00; // Transition to state A
end
endcase
end
end
always @(state) begin
case (state)
2'b00: out_reg = 1'b0; // Output 0 in state A
2'b01: out_reg = 1'b1; // Output 1 in state B
endcase
end
assign out = out_reg;
endmodule
endmodule

module top_module (
input clk,
input in,
input reset,
output reg out
);
reg [1:0] state;
parameter B = 2'b00;
parameter A = 2'b01;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= B;
end else begin
case (state)
B: begin
if (in) begin
state <= A;
end else begin
state <= B;
end
end
A: begin
if (in) begin
state <= A;
end else begin
state <= B;
end
end
endcase
end
end
always @(state) begin
case (state)
B: begin
out <= 1'b1;
end
A: begin
out <= 1'b0;
end
endcase
end
endmodule

module top_module (
input clk,
input in,
input areset,
output out
);
reg [1:0] state;
wire next_state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset) begin
state <= 2'b00; // reset to state A
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
assign next_state = (state == 2'b00 && in) ? 2'b01 :
(state == 2'b01 && in) ? 2'b01 :
(state == 2'b01 && !in) ? 2'b10 :
(state == 2'b10 && in) ? 2'b11 :
(state == 2'b10 && !in) ? 2'b00 :
(state == 2'b11 && in) ? 2'b01 :
(state == 2'b11 && !in) ? 2'b10 :
2'b00;
assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0;
endmodule

module top_module (
input in,
input [1:0] state,
output reg [1:0] next_state,
output out
);
always_comb begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // State A
if (in)
next_state = 2'b01; // Transition to State B
else
next_state = 2'b00; // Remain in State A
end
2'b01: begin // State B
if (in)
next_state = 2'b01; // Remain in State B
else
next_state = 2'b10; // Transition to State C
end
2'b10: begin // State C
if (in)
next_state = 2'b11; // Transition to State D
else
next_state = 2'b00; // Transition to State A
end
2'b11: begin // State D
if (in)
next_state = 2'b01; // Transition to State B
else
next_state = 2'b10; // Transition to State C
end
endcase
end
assign out = (state == 2'b11); // Output is high when in State D
endmodule
endmodule

module top_module (
input in,
input [3:0] state,
output reg [3:0] next_state,
output out
);
always @(state[A] or state[C] or in) begin
if (in == 1'b0) begin
next_state[A] = state[A] | state[C];
end else begin
next_state[A] = 4'b0;
end
end
always @(state[A] or state[B] or state[D] or in) begin
if (in == 1'b0) begin
next_state[B] = 4'b0;
end else begin
next_state[B] = state[A] | state[B] | state[D];
end
end
always @(state[B] or state[D] or in) begin
if (in == 1'b0) begin
next_state[C] = state[B] | state[D];
end else begin
next_state[C] = 4'b0;
end
end
always @(state[C] or in) begin
if (in == 1'b0) begin
next_state[D] = 4'b0;
end else begin
next_state[D] = state[C];
end
end
assign out = state[D];
endmodule
endmodule

input clk,
input in,
input reset,
output out
);
reg [1:0] state, next_state;

if (reset) begin
state <= 2'b00; // initial state A

state <= next_state;
end
end

case (state)
2'b00: begin // state A
if (in) begin
next_state = 2'b01; // transition to state B
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // remain in state A
end
end
2'b01: begin // state B
if (in) begin
next_state = 2'b01; // remain in state B
end else begin
next_state = 2'b10; // transition to state C
end
end
2'b10: begin // state C
if (in) begin
next_state = 2'b11; // transition to state D
end else begin
next_state = 2'b00; // transition to state A
end
end
2'b11: begin // state D
if (in) begin
next_state = 2'b01; // transition to state B
end else begin
next_state = 2'b10; // transition to state C
end
end
endcase
end
assign out = (state == 2'b11) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0;
endmodule

detail_description: The PS/2 mouse protocol sends messages that are three bytes long. However, within a continuous byte stream, it's not obvious where messages start and end. The only indication is that the first byte of each three byte message always has in[3]=1 (but in[3] of the other two bytes may be 1 or 0 depending on data). We want a finite state machine that will search for message boundaries when given an input byte stream. The algorithm we'll use is to discard bytes until we see one with in[3]=1. We then assume that this is byte 1 of a message, and signal the receipt of a message once all 3 bytes have been received (done). The FSM should signal done in the cycle immediately after the third byte of each message was successfully received. Reset should be active high synchronous.

The FSM should signal done in the cycle immediately after the third byte of each message was successfully received. Reset should be active high synchronous.

detail_description: In many (older) serial communications protocols, each data byte is sent along with a start bit and a stop bit, to help the receiver delimit bytes from the stream of bits. One common scheme is to use one start bit (0), 8 data bits, and 1 stop bit (1). The line is also at logic 1 when nothing is being transmitted (idle). Design a finite state machine that will identify when bytes have been correctly received when given a stream of bits. It needs to identify the start bit, wait for all 8 data bits, then verify that the stop bit was correct. If the stop bit does not appear when expected, the FSM must wait until it finds a stop bit before attempting to receive the next byte. Include a active-high synchronous reset. Note that the serial protocol sends the least significant bit first.

module top_module
(
input clk,
input areset,
input predict_valid,
input predict_taken,
output logic [31:0] predict_history,
input train_mispredicted,
input train_taken,
input [31:0] train_history
);
always @(posedge clk or negedge areset) begin
if (!areset) begin
predict_history <= 0;
end else begin
if (train_mispredicted) begin
predict_history <= {train_history, train_taken};
end else if (predict_valid) begin
predict_history <= predict_taken;
end
end
end
endmodule

    input areset,
    input predict_valid,

    output logic [31:0] predict_history,

    input train_taken,

);
detail_description: Build a 32-bit global history shift register, including support for rolling back state in response to a pipeline flush caused by a branch misprediction. When a branch prediction is made (predict_valid = 1), shift in predict_taken from the LSB side to update the branch history for the predicted branch. (predict_history[0] is the direction of the youngest branch.) When a branch misprediction occurs (train_mispredicted = 1), load the branch history register with the history after the completion of the mispredicted branch. This is the history before the mispredicted branch (train_history) concatenated with the actual result of the branch (train_taken). If both a prediction and misprediction occur at the same time, the misprediction takes precedence, because the pipeline flush will also flush out the branch that is currently making a prediction. predict_history is the value of the branch history register. areset is a positive edge triggered asynchronous reset that resets the history counter to zero.

solution:
module top_module
(
input clk,
input areset,
input predict_valid,
input predict_taken,
output logic [31:0] predict_history,
input train_mispredicted,
input train_taken,
input [31:0] train_history
);
always @(posedge clk or negedge areset) begin
if (areset == 0) begin
predict_history <= 0;
end else begin
if (train_mispredicted == 1) begin
predict_history <= {predict_history[30:0], train_taken};
end else if (predict_valid == 1) begin
predict_history <= {predict_history[30:0], predict_taken};
end
end
end
endmodule

module top_module (

);

out <= 0;
default:

endcase
end

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input areset,
input bump_left,
input bump_right,
output reg walk_left,
output reg walk_right
);
reg [1:0] state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset) begin
state <= 2'b10; // walking left
end else begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // walking right
if (bump_left || (bump_left && bump_right)) begin
state <= 2'b10; // walking left
end
end
2'b10: begin // walking left
if (bump_right || (bump_left && bump_right)) begin
state <= 2'b00; // walking right
end
end
endcase
end
end
always @(state) begin
case (state)
2'b00: begin // walking right
walk_left <= 1'b0;
walk_right <= 1'b1;
end
2'b10: begin // walking left
walk_left <= 1'b1;
walk_right <= 1'b0;
end
endcase
end
endmodule

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input areset,
input bump_left,
input bump_right,
output reg walk_left,
output reg walk_right
);
reg [1:0] state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge areset) begin
if (areset) begin
state <= 2'b10; // walking left
end else begin
case (state)
2'b10: begin // walking left
if (bump_right) begin
state <= 2'b01; // walking right
end
end
2'b01: begin // walking right
if (bump_left) begin
state <= 2'b10; // walking left
end
end
endcase
end
end
always @(state) begin
case (state)
2'b10: begin // walking left
walk_left <= 1;
walk_right <= 0;
end
2'b01: begin // walking right
walk_left <= 0;
walk_right <= 1;
end
endcase
end
endmodule

input ar,

solution:
module top_module (
input clk,
input reset,
input w,
output reg z
);
reg [2:0] state, next_state;
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 3'b000;
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
always @(state or w) begin
case (state)
3'b000: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b000;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b001;
end
end
3'b001: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b010;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b011;
end
end
3'b010: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b001;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b100;
end
end
3'b011: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b100;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b101;
end
end
3'b100: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b000;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b110;
end
end
3'b101: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b110;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b101;
end
end
3'b110: begin
if (w) begin
next_state = 3'b100;
end else begin
next_state = 3'b010;
end
end
default: begin
next_state = 3'b000;
end
endcase
end
always @(state) begin
if (state == 3'b101 || state == 3'b110) begin
z <= 1'b1;
end else begin
z <= 1'b0;
end
end
endmodule

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
output reg [9:0] q);
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
q <= 0;
end else begin
if (q == 999) begin
q <= 0;
end else begin
q <= q + 1;
end
end
end
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input data,
	output start_shifting);
detail_description: Build a finite-state machine that searches for the sequence 1101 in an input bit stream. When the sequence is found, it should set start_shifting to 1, forever, until reset. Reset is active high synchronous.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
input data,
output start_shifting);
reg [3:0] state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 4'b0000;
end else begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0001;
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000;
end
end
4'b0001: begin
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0011;
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000;
end
end
4'b0011: begin
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0011;
end else begin
state <= 4'b0110;
end
end
4'b0110: begin
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b1111;
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000;
end
end
default: begin
state <= 4'b1111;
end
endcase
end
end
assign start_shifting = (state == 4'b1111) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0;
endmodule
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input data,
	output start_shifting);
detail_description: Build a finite-state machine that searches for the sequence 1101 in an input bit stream. When the sequence is found, it should set start_shifting to 1, forever, until reset. Reset is active high synchronous.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
input data,
output start_shifting);
reg [3:0] state;
reg [3:0] next_state;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 4'b0000; // initial state S
end else begin
state <= next_state;
end
end
assign start_shifting = (state == 4'b1111); // output is high if state is Done, low otherwise
always @* begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin // S
if (data) begin
next_state = 4'b0001; // S1
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // S
end
end
4'b0001: begin // S1
if (data) begin
next_state = 4'b0011; // S11
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // S
end
end
4'b0011: begin // S11
if (data) begin
next_state = 4'b0011; // S11
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0110; // S110
end
end
4'b0110: begin // S110
if (data) begin
next_state = 4'b1111; // Done
end else begin
next_state = 4'b0000; // S
end
end
4'b1111: begin // Done
next_state = 4'b1111; // Done
end
endcase
end
endmodule

prompt:
module top_module(
	input clk,
	input reset,
	input data,
	output start_shifting);
detail_description: Build a finite-state machine that searches for the sequence 1101 in an input bit stream. When the sequence is found, it should set start_shifting to 1, forever, until reset. Reset is active high synchronous.

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
input data,
output start_shifting);
reg [3:0] state;
wire start_shifting_out;
always @(posedge clk or posedge reset) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 4'b0000; // initial state S
end else begin
case (state)
4'b0000: begin // state S
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0001; // next state S1
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000; // next state S
end
end
4'b0001: begin // state S1
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0011; // next state S11
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000; // next state S
end
end
4'b0011: begin // state S11
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b0011; // next state S11
end else begin
state <= 4'b0110; // next state S110
end
end
4'b0110: begin // state S110
if (data) begin
state <= 4'b1111; // next state Done
end else begin
state <= 4'b0000; // next state S
end
end
4'b1111: begin // state Done
state <= 4'b1111; // next state Done
end
endcase
end
end
assign start_shifting_out = (state == 4'b1111) ? 1'b1 : 1'b0;
assign start_shifting = start_shifting_out;
endmodule
endmodule

solution:
module top_module(
input clk,
input reset,
output shift_ena);
reg [2:0] state;
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (reset) begin
state <= 3'b000;
end else begin
case (state)
3'b000: begin
state <= 3'b001;
end
3'b001: begin
state <= 3'b010;
end
3'b010: begin
state <= 3'b011;
end
3'b011: begin
state <= 3'b100;
end
default: begin
state <= 3'b100;
end
endcase
end
end
assign shift_ena = (state == 3'b000) || (state == 3'b001) || (state == 3'b010) || (state == 3'b011);
endmodule
endmodule

module top_module(
input clk,
input shift_ena,
input count_ena,
input data,
output reg [3:0] q);
reg [3:0] shift_reg;
always @(posedge clk) begin
if (shift_ena) begin
shift_reg <= {data, shift_reg[3:1]};
end
if (count_ena) begin
shift_reg <= shift_reg - 1;
end
end
assign q = shift_reg;
endmodule

module top_module(
input clk,
input load,
input [1:0] ena,
input [99:0] data,

reg [99:0] shift_reg;

For example, sign-extending 4'b0101 (5) to 8 bits results in 8'b00000101 (5), while sign-extending 4'b1101 (-3) to 8 bits results in 8'b11111101 (-3).
